DOC.HEAD: Polish Zloty Devalued
DOC.TEXT: The National Bank of Poland is devaluing the Polish zloty by 32 percent, Polish media reported Sunday, in another step aimed at making the currency convertible and improving trade prospects. Until now, the zloty could not be used for international transactions because it is not convertible to other currencies. Polish radio said Sunday that the new official exchange rate set by the bank will be 9,500 zlotys to $1 as of Monday. Banks and exchange offices are closed on New Year's Day. It was the largest devaluation since Parliament approved the non-Communist government in September. The zloty has been devalued 12 times since then. The government is supporting the effort to reduce the gap between the official rate of the zloty and a legal, though unofficial rate available to all citizens. On Saturday, the unofficial rate legalized earlier this year, which reflects the former black market rate, hovered at about 9,000 zlotys to $1. The government previously announced it hoped the zloty would be completely convertible by Monday, but Finance Ministry officials explained last week that the unofficial rate will still exist. However, the government intends to try to keep the gap between the two rates to a minimum through bank intervention. Creation of covertibility of the zloty has been a centerpiece of economic legislation passed by both houses of Parliament last week. The devaluation also occurs before major price hikes expected Monday.
